content.description:
This is the classic high ball slab mantel on the West face, just left of the Descent Crack.

Opening moves are casual, staying right, to a smear intensive mantle using the large black xenolith.
content.location: West Side Stories is the predominant rounded slab on the West side of East Crack Boulder.

content.description:
A couple of different fun variations ascend the West Face, between the South Side Dihedral and the Descent Crack.

Right variation is a bit harder.
content.location: West face of South Crack Boulder.

content.description:
Extremely technical, core wrenching and somewhat contrived.

Still very  sporty and worth while.

Sit start low, heal hook right and work a few compression moves before it is  possible to fall to left side of Arête. Pinching arête, with high feet throw for the horizontal finger crack.
content.location: Climbs the obvious overhanging arête making up the right side of East Crack. Sit start down low and right from beginning of crack.

climbs.name: South Side Dihedral  AKA Daniels Dihedral.

content.description: South Side Dihedral climbs the obvious short sweet and clean dihedral on the south side of this boulder. The crux is the mantel at the top.
content.location: South Side of East Crack Boulder.

content.description: NSOW is the obvious  Off Width/Squeeze Chimney on the North side of the East Crack Boulder. Kind of a one move wonder, Fun lay Back moves get you into the squeeze. Either chimney from here, or continue lay back (airy) to large incut jug up and left.
content.location: North side of East Crack Boulder.

climbs.name: Guidos in Bondage AKA The Northwest Arête.

content.description: Guidos in Bondage is the other classic Arête on this Rock, next to Tech 9. Climb the high ball arête, that makes up the left side of North Side Off Width. Sit start low, technical arête, compression and crimping moves, will get you to the top out jug. Crux is probably high leaving the horizontal  crimpy flake to last arête move just befor the jug. Committing  Mantle!
content.protection: Pads are nice shit poor landing. Don't fall at the crux!!! :)
content.location: North side of East Crack Boulder. Arête formed from left side of off width crack.

content.description: This is the high ball slab following sloper ledges just to the left of the Classic East Crack.
content.location: East side of the East Crack Boulder.

content.description: This is the awkward squeeze chimney just to the right of the Tech 9 Arête. Can be climbed on outside of chimney.
content.location: East side of East Crack boulder.  Obvious  yosemite-esque Squeeze starting of spike.

content.description: This is probably the easiest most  splitter line at Melrose. As a matter of fact it is the only worth while crack to do. High ball splitter fingers, hands, and fists make this a must!
content.location: This climb is the obvious left trending diagonal crack, on the east side of the furthest eastern boulder in the Creek Side Cirque.  It is easily seen from the sport park and would be the first climb you see as you make the approach.

content.description: Classic low ball traverse, that follows the lowest predominant features around the entire rock. Better if done right to left but can be done vice versa. Three cruxes with on ok landing.
content.location: Can be started anywhere, traverse low!

content.description: This is the clean finger crack following the right trending ramp splitting the West face.  Also the common down climb for all other routes on this boulder.
content.location: This route is located on the West face of the East Crack boulder. Also the decent.
